Award.AwardTitle: CREST Center for Energy and Sustainability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The California State University, Los Angeles (Cal State L.A.) proposes to establish a new CREST Center for Energy and Sustainability (CEaS). CEaS embodies a new vision for a new CREST center that builds on existing strengths of Cal State L.A.?s Colleges of Engineering, Computer Science, and Technology (ECST) and Natural and Social Sciences (NSS). The Center?s mission is threefold: 1) to increase the number of underrepresented students in STEM fields and, especially, to put them on a path towards the professoriate; 2) to conduct innovative, multidisciplinary, research in energy and sustainability; and 3) to increase public awareness and engage policymakers in this nascent movement. CSLA will be have a consortium of partners that includes representatives from institutions (i.e., middle and high schools, and a community college) with highly diverse student populations, public and private Ph.D.-granting institutions, the largest energy providers and utilities in the U.S., private industry, the Los Angeles Mayor?s office, and national laboratories. Collaborating with these institutions helps us pursue a vision of conducting cutting edge research and transforming sustainable energy from environmental chic to accessible technologies that excite 6th-graders and benefit society.

Under the unifying theme of Energy and Sustainability, the four center subprojects will engage in research to address the three cornerstones of energy sustainability: diversity in energy sources, efficiency in energy use, and long-term sustainability. The ?biofuels combustion? subproject will immediately tackle research projects to make current combustion more efficient and less polluting. The ?photovoltaics? subproject will work on developing highly efficient and inexpensive photovoltaic cells. The ?fuel cells? subproject is interested in creating micro-fuel cells for applications in portable electronics. Finally, the ?carbon sequestration? component is interested in understanding the impacts of carbon capture and storage on the environment. Together, these four subprojects have a good mix of scientists and engineers with both short- and long-term research agendas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2009, Cal State LA was awarded a CREST Phase I grant (NSF-HRD-0932421) to establish the Center for Energy and Sustainability (CEaS). Establishment of this Center is based on the considerations that (1) development of sustainable energy is of national importance and (2) involvement of students in research projects in this area will help shape many future scientists, engineers, and policy makers. For the past six years (including one year of no-cost extension), faculty from the Colleges of Natural and Social Sciences (NSS) and Engineering, Computer Science, and Technology (ECST) have tripled their publications by involving 90 students (42 of them are pursuing or have earned advanced degrees in STEM fields). The Center faculty have also garnered additional grants totaling 9 million dollars. As a result of significant elevation of research productivity and enhanced educational efforts, we have 1) expanded the institutional efforts in recruitment, retention, and graduation of students in the STEM fields; 2) transformed the Center into a nationally recognized research entity with emphases on energy and energy-related materials and technologies, 3) initiated innovative and multidisciplinary research among the Center faculty and through collaborations with industry and partnering institutions; and 4) directly (through financial support of and close interaction with student fellows and broadly (thorough workshops, seminar series, outreach activities etc.) impacted a large number of students (total benefited from this project exceeds 150.  Cal State LA has new initiatives that will help accomplish the above objectives including expanding the highly successful student mentoring programs in both colleges, creation of an M. S. degree in Materials Science and Engineering, establishment of a regional material characterization/testing core facility, and targeting hires of three assistant professors with expertise on materials research. The consortium of partners includes representatives from community colleges and high schools, all of which have highly diverse student populations, Ph.D.-granting institutions, and private industry. The dedication of the Center faculty to mentoring underserved students through well designed projects will help improve the underrepresentation of these students in STEM fields.

Research Projects: Four synergistic subprojects and three supplemental projects under the unified theme of 'Energy and Sustainability were successfully implemented and performed. For example, the 'Microfluidic-based Fuel Cells and Optimization' subproject developed chip-based fuel cells and efficient catalysts for powering portable devices. In the subproject on 'Advanced Materials for Photovoltaic Cells', new inorganic and organic nanomaterial have been integrated into photovoltaic cells so that electricity can be generated in an efficient and environmentally friendly manner. All projects are spearheaded by highly productive researchers with a strong track record of working with students. Our senior faculty will continue contributing to their respective fields while mentoring a new group of faculty, many of whom are role models to our students; CREST and university support will ensure that the new faculty have the resources to enable them to successfully achieve their project goals. In addition to existing partners (e.g., Boeing, Southern California Edison, and Cal Tech), through supplemental projects, we have established new and productive working relationships with institutions such as Oak Crest Institute of Science and Portland State University.

Intellectual Merit: The research subprojects are transformative and ambitious and address both fundamental and applied problems in energy science and technology. These projects embrace the concept of sustainable energy by tackling problems impeding the development of fossil-fuel-free energy and techniques that conserve energy. Cal State LA has established  collaborations with local companies as well as a number of research-intensive institutions,  with whom Cal State LA can utilize resources to make significant progress in the endeavors. As the research projects are integrated with our curricular development efforts, they will also help develop innovative approaches in science/engineering education.    

Broader Impacts: The vision for CEaS goes above and beyond research to activities that have engaged a highly diverse group of pre-college and college students. A strong mentoring and recruiting mechanism is firmly in place that continuously serve the students in their academic and research programs. The research human resources infrastructure we developed will impact Cal State LA’s research/education capacity and the surrounding community for many years to come in terms of workforce and talents for energy research and urban sustainability. Through the innovative recruitment and public outreach efforts, the impacts will further be amplified and be long lasting. The results and accomplishments in the past six years paved the way for many new initiatives and activities (e.g., a new master's degree in Materials Science and Engineering and a core research facility for materials characterization and testing, and partnership with research institutions such as Penn State, UC-Riverside, UMass etc.). Coupled with a strong institutional support, CEaS is on pace to become a sustainable center of excellence and a cradle of future leaders in science and technology.
